metadata.title: Fabrication of a highly protective silane composite coating with limited water uptake utilizing functionalized carbon nano-tubes

sections.text:
Composites Part B 175 (2019) 107109
Available online 5 July 2019 1359-8368/© 2019 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
Fabrication of a highly protective silane composite coating with limited water uptake utilizing functionalized carbon nano-tubes
Sajjad Akbarzadeh a, Reza Naderi a,**, Mohammad Mahdavian b,*
a School of Metallurgy and Materials Engineering, College of Engineering, University of Tehran, P.O. Box, 11155-4563, Tehran, Iran b Department of Surface Coatings and Corrosion, Institute for Color Science and Technology, P.O. Box, 16765-654, Tehran, Iran
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Carbon nano-tubes Silane composite coatings Water uptake EIS
A B S T R A C T
Water uptake is an influential parameter on the protective properties of coatings. Carbon nano-tubes (CNTs) with different oxidation levels were used in this work to decrease water uptake of silane composite coating. The water uptake of the single-layer coatings was monitored using electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS). In this assessment, power-law formula and effective medium theory (EMT) were exploited considering the parallel combination of the coating and electrolyte. EIS results showed that an increase in oxidation level of CNTs improved the protective functioning of the silane sol-gel coatings due to decrease in water uptake of the coatings.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Water uptake is the first step of the degradation as it provides a pathway for aggressive ions to access the metal surface. Evaluation of the water uptake is very useful to calculate the lifetime of the coating and duration of the protection [1–3]. Both resistance and capacitance of the coating change by water penetration [4].
Protective coatings are used to make a barrier between the environment and substrate to prohibit water direct contact with the substrate [5]. Silane coatings have been attracted much attention according to the anti-corrosive and eco-friendly properties [6]. However, it couldn’t last for longer times, so some authors investigated the addition of some materials to the silane-based coatings to improve the corrosion performance. Parhizkar et al. examined the addition of functionalized graphene oxide to a silane-based coating. It was shown that due to the compatibility of functionalized GO nanofillers with silane matrix and blocking porosities in silane coatings through covalent bonding between silanol groups on the surface of functionalized nanofillers and silanol groups in the silane matrix the corrosion performance was enhanced [7]. Al-Saadi examined the corrosion performance of hexagonal boron nitride impregnated silane composite coating on the magnesium alloys substrate [8]. They utilized electrochemical measurements to show nearly five-fold enhancement in corrosion resistance of Mg alloys. Due to the fact that even intact kinds of coatings have some pores or defects which causes water reaches the substrate [9], electrochemical
impedance spectroscopy (EIS) providing the extent of coating capacitance is a popular technique to determine the absorbed water [10–12]. Brusher and Kingsbury estimated the volume fraction of the water by changing the coating capacitance using the following equation [13,14]:
φ ¼ K log
�
Ct=C0
�
logðεwÞ (1)
where Ct is the coating capacitance at immersion at time t; C0 is the initial coating capacitance; εw is the water dielectric constant, and φ is the water volume fraction in the coating.
Ji et al. [15] applied Brasher and Kingsbury equation to show that the modified epoxy with γ-aminopropyltrimethoxy silane (γ-APS) absorbed less electrolyte than the neat one; therefore, had a better corrosion protective properties. Nguyen et al. [16] made a comparison between impedance measurements and gravimetry to calculate water uptake in the water-based coatings containing SrCrO4 or a mixture of Cr (VI)-free pigments. They observed that the water volume fractions calculated based on dielectric constant values, linear combination formula and gravimetry method confirmed each other. Moreno et al. [17] employed Brasher and Kingsbury equation and two other models (the discrete (DM) and continuous (CM) models proposed by Bellucci and Nicodemo [18]) to evaluate the water absorption. The results of the three models were different but they revealed the same results at saturation point. Also, they exhibited that the water-uptake depends on both
* Corresponding author. ** Corresponding author.
E-mail addresses: rezanaderi@ut.ac.ir (R. Naderi), mahdavian-m@icrc.ac.ir (M. Mahdavian).
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Composites Part B
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/compositesb
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.compositesb.2019.107109 Received 16 March 2019; Received in revised form 3 June 2019; Accepted 4 July 2019
Composites Part B 175 (2019) 107109
the thickness and nature of the coating. According to the fact that the surface roughness makes the coating a non-ideal capacitor and causes inhomogeneous water uptake in the film, employing capacitance instead of constant phase element (CPE) for evaluation of the water uptake may lead to incorrect results [19,20]. Amand et al. [21] considered some assumptions to use CPE for determination of water uptake: (i) the electrolyte absorption of the coating decreased from electrolyte/coating interface to coating/substrate interface; (ii) water-uptake variation through the coating could be calculated by power-law formula; (iii) from parallel combination of the coating and electrolyte material, effective medium theory (EMT) was used to calculate the resistivity and permittivity profiles of the diffused-electrolyte; (iv) some pores, which were stretched from coating/electrolyte interface to substrate/coating interface, made a low resistivity path. They proved the inhomogeneous water-uptake caused by CPE behavior of 2024 aluminum coated with polyaminoamide, 3 glycidoxypropylethoxysilane, tetraethylorthosilicate and epoxy resin which was immersed in 0.5 M NaCl solution. This work was promoted in the present research for the hybrid sol-gel coating composed of glycidoxypropyltrimethoxysilane (γ-GPS), methyltriethoxysilane (MTES) and tetraethylorthosilicate (TEOS) by another equivalent circuit, determining the amount of water-uptake, resistivity, and permittivity profiles. In this work, the effect of the addition of carbon nano-tubes (CNTs) with different oxidation levels on the silane coating water uptake was also evaluated. To this end, we considered all elements of the impedance circuit in the theoretical calculation.

sections.heading: 2. Theory
sections.text:
We assumed that all the pores are aligned from the electrolyte/ coating interface to the bulk of the coating and some of these pores reach the coating/metal interface. The depth of some pores is the same as the thickness of the coating and the rest of them has smaller depth. A dimensionless coordinate (ξ) is defined by the position along the perpendicular coordinate to the electrolyte/coating and coating/substrate interfaces as below:
ξ ¼ x δ
(2)
where x is the distance from the substrate/coating interface and δ the coating thickness. Therefore, different planes equidistant to the interface are located at different ξ. Due to the fact that the amount of electrolyte penetrating into the coating film depends on the depth of each pore, different numbers of pores exist at equidistant planes leading to different
local electrolyte volume fractions φ(ξ). It is worth to note that each position of the elemental parallel layer is composed of either the coating material or the electrolyte.
Effective medium theory (EMT) formulas are used to clarify the dependence of the permittivity (ε) and resistivity (ρ) profiles to φ(ξ). Various EMT formulas have been suggested [22,23]. Owing to the work of Amand et al. [21], a linear combination of resistivity and permittivity is more suitable for CPE impedance response of uneven water uptake, i. e.,
ρðξÞ 1 ¼ ρw 1 φðξÞ þ ρc 1½1 – φðξÞ� (3)
εðξÞ ¼ εw φðξÞ þ εc ½1 – φðξÞ� (4)
where the subscripts “c” and “w” refer to the coating and water, respectively.
The impedance of CPE is calculated with the use of Eq. (5):
ZCPE ¼ 1
½jω�αQ (5)
where Q is CPE admittance, ω the angular frequency and α a factor that determines the ideality of the CPE factor changing from 0 to 1(for ideal capacitor α ¼ 1).
The relationship between the CPE exponent α and power-law exponent γ is shown in Eq. (6).
α ¼ γ 1 γ
(6)
To calculate the Zc, only the pores that do not reach the coating/ substrate interface are considered. For the through pores, Rpore is assumed. According to this hypothesis, the variation of φ(ξ) is from φ(0) at ξ ¼ 0 to φ(δ) at ξ ¼ 1 [24]. In the manner of this assumption and power-law φ(ξ) is expressed as
φðξÞ ¼ φðδÞξγ
1þ φðδÞðξγ 1Þ (7)
Coating impedance (Zc) can be represented as Eq. (8) [21]. By water ingression, the impedance of the coating decreases. Water ingression into the coating provides conductive pathways for aggressive ions to diffuse into the coating and to reach the substrate. This expression is based on the assumption that each elemental layer is a parallel combination of a resistance ρ(ξ)dξ and a capacitance ε(ξ)ε0/dξ.
ZcðωÞ ¼ δ Z 1
0 1 ρðξÞ 1 þ jωεðξÞε0 dξ (8)
In this work, as there were two-time constants in the EIS diagram, the two-time constant equivalent circuit shown in Fig. 1 was employed to analyze the whole system impedance. All the elements of the circuit, including electrolyte, charge transfer and pore resistance and CPE elements of the double layer and coating impedance) were considered for evaluating water uptake. Therefore, the electrode impedance, Z, was calculated by Eq. (9), which is different from that (Eq. (10)) used by Amand et al. [21].

sections.heading: 3.1. Materials
sections.text: Steel substrates (3 � 6 cm2) were abraded with sand papers with grades of 400, 600, 800 and 1000 that were degreased with acetone after abrasion. The pH of acid cleaning solution and silane coating solution were respectively controlled by sulfuric acid and acetic acid which were obtained from Zakaria Jahrom Co. (Iran). Benzothiazole as an inhibitor for acid cleaning solution was purchased from Merck (Germany). Glycidoxypropyltrimethoxysilane (γ - GPS), methyltriethoxysilane (MTES), and tetraethylorthosilicate (TEOS) were obtained from Aldrich as silane coating precursors. Ethyl alcohol (96%) and nitric acid were supplied by Zakaria Jahrom Co. (Iran) in order to prepare the silane coating solutions and CNT’s oxidation solution, respectively. Pristine multi-walled CNTs (length ¼ 1–10 μm and the number of walls ¼ 3-15) were purchased from Nanostartech (Iran).

sections.heading: 3.2. Oxidation of the CNTs
sections.text:
A 75 mL of the sulfuric acid 75% with 25 mL of the nitric acid 65% were poured to a beaker. Then 0.5 g of the CNTs was added and stirred for three times (8 h, 12 and 24) at 100 �C to oxidize CNTs with different
S. Akbarzadeh et al.
Composites Part B 175 (2019) 107109
oxidation levels respectively denoted as C1, C2, and C3. Afterward, 500 mL of distilled water was added to reduce the acid concentration. Then, the suspensions were centrifuged for 15 min at speed of 4500 rpm to separate the oxidized CNTs from an acidic solution. The CNTs were washed with 250 mL of distilled water several times through cycles of 2 min ultrasonic dispersion and centrifugation.

sections.heading: 3.3. Sample preparation
sections.text:
The steel panels were immersed in a sulfuric acid solution (pH 3) for 10 s containing Benzothiazole as an inhibitor; then, immediately rinsed with distilled water and dried.
Aqueous silane solution was prepared using the three precursors (γ-GPS, MTES, and TEOS) equally. Then, water 40% (w/w) and ethyl alcohol 40% (w/w) was added to the mixture of silane. Acetic acid was used to adjust the pH of the silane solution at 3. The mixture was
magnetically mixed at a rate of 750 rpm for 24 h [25]. To obtain silane nanocomposites, 0.005 g of CNTs were added to 10 g of water/ethyl alcohol mixture with pH 3. The mixture was ultrasonicated for 30 min; then the CNTs dispersion was added to the silane mixture and stirred about 15 min.
The acid treated steel samples were dipped into the silane solution for 1 min; then, the coated samples dried at ambient temperature for 24 h after curing at 150 �C for 30 min [25,26].
The coatings were designated as Sil (neat silane), SiC1 (silane þ C1), SiC2 (silane þ C2) and SiC3 (Silane þ C3).

sections.heading: 3.4. Characterization methods
sections.text:
The zeta potential of CNTs was obtained by using the Horiba SZ-100 instrument. The FTIR spectra of the CNTs were obtained using KBr pellet method by a Perkin-Elmer instrument at the wavenumber range of 4000-
S. Akbarzadeh et al.
Composites Part B 175 (2019) 107109
450 cm 1 using sixteen scans for each sample. The SEM images of the CNTs were taken on a dried droplet of CNTs dispersion in the water (0.01 wt %) on a glass sheet using Cam Scan MV2300, Czech Republic instrument.
Contact angle measurement was done to examine the wettability of the silane coatings in the presence of CNTs.
FTIR spectra of the coating substrate was attained before and after immersion. For obtaining the coating FTIR spectra before immersion, small droplets of the silane coating solutions were dropped on a Teflon film then dried and cured according to the procedure mentioned in section 3.3. Powder of the silane coating was prepared by collecting the fine grains. In order to acquire FTIR spectra of the coating after immersion, silane-based composite coatings were applied on the substrate dipped in the 0.1 M NaCl for 6 h. After that, they were washed with distilled water and dried. Using a sharp knife some scratches were made; then, the coatings were removed from substrate to make powders. The KBr pellet method was used to prepare FTIR specimens.
Cross-section and surface image of the coatings after 18 h immersion in the 0.1 M NaCl solution was examined by SEM to illustrate the thickness of coatings and corrosion products, respectively. The coated samples were washed with distilled water and thoroughly dried before imaging.

sections.heading: 3.5. Electrochemical measurements
sections.text:
Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was employed to examine the electrochemical behavior of the coated samples. For this purpose, samples were sealed with a mixture of beeswax-colophony while an area of 1.0 cm2 was unmasked. After 1, 3 and 6 h immersion in 0.1 M NaCl solution at open circuit potential (OCP), ACM-Gill instrument at the frequency domain of 100 kHz to 0.01 Hz were exploited to gather electrochemical information using a sine wave of 10 mV amplitude peak to peak. For repeatability, EIS was examined on three replicates.
Polarization curves of coatings were obtained by an ACM-Gill instrument utilizing a scan rate of 1 mV/s from 250 mV to þ250 mV of OCP after 6 h immersion in 0.1 M NaCl.
To achieve electrochemical data a three-electrode cell was used with
a platinum auxiliary electrode, saturated calomel electrode (SCE) as a reference electrode and the prepared sample as a working electrode. In order to analyze the impedance data with the equivalent circuit in Fig. 1a, Zveiw3.1c software was used. Analytical expression and the provided model (Eq. (9)) were employed in MATLAB R2013a for evaluation of the water uptake, and resistivity and permittivity profile.

sections.heading: 4.1.1. Fourier transform infra-red spectroscopy (FTIR)
sections.text: The FTIR spectra of pristine CNTs (PC) and oxidized CNTs (C1, C2, and C3) after mixing with KBr to form a bullet prior are displayed in Fig. 2. No specific absorption band was found in PC, meaning there was not any functional group on the shelf of pristine CNTs. The specific absorption bands at 3418 and 1065 cm 1 were due to the (O-H) stretching and out of plane torsion, respectively; either for the moisture of the atmosphere or the presence of hydroxyl group on the surface of nano-tubes [27]. By increasing the level of oxidation, O-H peak at 1065 cm 1 was intensified due to the fact that there are more O-H groups on the CNTs after oxidation. The peaks at 2922 and 2851 cm 1 were referred to C-H band. The broad shoulder at 3400-2500 cm 1 detected for C3 was an indication for acid O-H stretches [28]. The bands at 1712 and 1627 cm 1 showed the presence of C¼O band attributing to carboxylic acid and ketone/Quinone, respectively [29,30]. By increasing the extent of oxidation to reach C3 sample, new peaks appeared in the range of 1200-900 cm 1, where the peaks at 1171, 1065, and 881 cm 1 wavenumbers may correspond to C-O stretching vibration of the carboxylic acid group, O-H out of plane torsion and isolated aromatic C–H out of plane bending mode vibration, respectively [30,31]. The peak at 550 cm 1 was due to C-H bending [32]. Increase in the intensity of this peak can be attributed to the formation of structural defects in the CNTs structure upon oxidation.

sections.heading: 4.1.2. Zeta potential
sections.text: Carboxylic acid imparted a negative charge on the Nano-tubes surface resulted in electrostatic repulsion among the CNTs. It should be noted that pristine CNTs with no functional groups have no charge at pH ~7 [33]. Fig. 3 depicts the zeta potential of various types of CNTs within the pH range of 3–7. It was obvious that by increasing the time of oxidation, the zeta potential was decreased and functional groups existed on the surface of the CNTs obtained a more negative charge. As indicated in Fig. 3, C3 had the lowest zeta potential in the mentioned pH range and could be expected to have better dispersion stability in the silane solution [34].

sections.heading: 4.1.3. SEM
sections.text: SEM images of CNT’s particles is exhibited in Fig. 4. It was clear that by increasing the time of the oxidation process, the tendency to form less agglomerated structures increased. This result was in a good agreement with the results of zeta potential measurements revealing higher repulsive forces between CNTs by increasing the extent of oxidation. In other words, the oxidation induces negative charge to the CNTs leading to an increase in electrostatic repulsive forces [35]. The longer the CNTs oxidation time, the more carboxylic acid groups would exist on the surface of CNTs; therefore, these higher repulsive forces resulted in less agglomerated structure. As it was illustrated C3 had the least agglomerated structure and the best dispersion among the other CNTs.

sections.heading: 4.2. Characterization and fabrication of the coating
4.2.1. FTIR and contact angle measurement
sections.text:
The FTIR spectra of the coatings in the presence and absence of CNTs are shown in Fig. 5. The absorption bands at 3433 and 1629 cm 1 for stretching and bending vibration of O-H were related to either water, or
S. Akbarzadeh et al.
Composites Part B 175 (2019) 107109
unreacted hydrolyzed silane, or hydroxyl groups on the CNTs. The silanol (Si-OH) sign appeared at 900 cm 1. The absorption bands at the 2934 and 2883 cm 1 may refer to the stretching vibrations of the C-H band [36].
The peak at 1277 cm 1 was attributed to Si-C of silane compounds [37]. The interaction between the carboxylic groups of CNTs and silane network was evidenced by asymmetric vibration and bending vibration of Si-O-C peak at 1098 and 696 cm 1, respectively. In the neat silane, the shoulder at 1098 cm 1 wavenumber might be due to the ladder-like
polymer. The (Si-O-Si) asymmetric vibration and bending vibration were shown at the 1050 and 465 cm 1 peaks which were enhanced by increasing the rate of CNTs oxidation [38]. The peak ratio of the O-H/Si-O-Si of the samples was followed as 2.45, 1.89, 1.59 and 0.77 for Sil, SiC1, SiC2, and SiC3, respectively. The decrement in O-H/Si-O-Si intensity ratio indicated elevation in the extent of silane coating condensation by the increase in the extent of CNTs oxidation. Besides filling of the micropores, the oxidized CNTs can improve the Si-O-Si clusters and enhance the barrier properties of the silane coating.
S. Akbarzadeh et al.
Composites Part B 175 (2019) 107109
Contact angle results are provided in Fig. 5. According to the results, the wettability of the coatings was diminished by incorporation of oxidized CNTs. Considering the increase in hydrophilicity of CNTs by increase in oxidation extent, an increase in hydrophobicity of silane coatings incorporating CNTs was quite interesting. The higher the extent of CNTs oxidation, the higher was the hydrophobicity of the silane
coating. Upon condensation, hydrophilic silanol groups react to form SiO-Si band which is less hydrophilic in nature. This result was in good agreement with FTIR results showing higher condensation in the presence of more oxidized CNTs. Achieving a denser silane film network by the inclusion of functionalized graphene oxide has been reported in the literature which is in good agreement with the results of this work [39].
The FTIR spectra of silane-based coating after 6 h immersion in 0.1 M NaCl are provided in Fig. 6. The adsorption bands related to Si-OH and Si-O-Si showed a little bit shift in wavenumber. It is noteworthy to mention that the O-H peak at 1625 cm 1 of SiC3 had the lowest intensity indicating the minimum amount of water diffused through the coating. Also, SiC3 had the maximum intensity of the Si-O-Si peak even after 6 h exposure time showing the highest crosslinking among the other samples even after immersion period. The peak ratio of the O-H/Si-O-Si of the samples followed the order as SiC3 < SiC2 < SiC1< Sil illustrating the less water content of the coating by utilizing CNTs with higher oxidation.

sections.heading: 4.2.2. SEM images
sections.text:
Fig. 7 shows the SEM cross-section images from the coated samples. Looking at this figure, it was evident that all the silane nanocomposites had higher thickness compared to the neat film, which may be due to their effect on the viscosity of silane solution leading to higher coating buildup [40]. It was clear that by increasing the extent of oxidation of CNTs, the thickness of the coatings decreased. This could be attributed to an increase in the number of bands between the silane network and shell of the CNTs. Increase in compactness of silane network due to interaction with CNTs has been reported in the literature [41]. A scheme showing the interaction of CNTs’ shell with the silane film network is provided in Fig. 8.
Fig. 9 shows the SEM images taken from the surface of silane coatings
S. Akbarzadeh et al.
Composites Part B 175 (2019) 107109
after 18 h immersion in the 0.1 M NaCl solution. Non-uniform destruction of the neat silane coating was obvious. By filling with oxidized CNTs, particularly in the case of SiC2 and SiC3, the samples showed a lower extent of corrosion. Minimum corrosion was observed in the case of SiC3, probably indicating the best protection among the test coating samples. This can be attributed to the contribution of CNTs in crosslinking with the silane molecules forming a denser network, as
confirmed by FTIR and contact angle measurements, and making ingression of the aggressive electrolyte to the coating more difficult.

sections.heading: 4.3. EIS assessment
sections.text:
EIS results of coated samples after 1, 3 and 6 h immersion in 0.1 M NaCl solution are presented in Nyquist diagrams (Fig. 10). An increase of the diameter of the semicircles in Nyquist diagrams attributed to pore resistance (Rpore) and charge transfer resistance (Rct) indicated that the CNTs inclusion in the sol-gel coatings improved the corrosion resistance. In the case of SiC3 sample, two semicircles were overlapped and showed the highest total diameter among the test samples.
Bode impedance and phase diagrams are illustrated after 1, 3 and 6 h immersion in 0.1 M NaCl solution in Fig. 11. Comparing the lowfrequency impedance (|Z|0.01 Hz) proved the higher corrosion resistance behavior by incorporation of CNTs with higher oxidation (SiC3 > SiC2 > SiC1> Sil). Also, phase angle diagrams clearly show that by embedding the oxidized CNTs into the silane matrix, the highfrequency phase angles shift to 90� reflecting improve in capacitive behavior and protective properties of the coatings [42].
The fitted curves are displayed as solid lines in Figs. 10 and 11. The double layer capacitance (Cdl) and coating capacitance (Cf) respectively calculated by using Eq. (11) and Eq. (12) [43], are provided in Fig. 12. A
S. Akbarzadeh et al.
Composites Part B 175 (2019) 107109
two-time constant equivalent circuit is shown in Fig. 13 was used to fit the EIS data.
Cdl ¼ Y 1=n 0; dl � Re � Rct Re þ Rct �ð1 nÞ=n
(11)
Cf ¼ Y 1=n 0; c R ð1 nÞ=n pore (12)
In these equations, Y0 and n represent the admittance of CPE and exponent of CPE, respectively.
Rpore and Rct obtained from curve fittings are listed in Table 1. Increasing the time of diffusion resulted in Rpore and Rct decrease due to the diffusion of electrolyte and aggressive ions. Because of water
diffusion, some pores in the coating were extended or some new pores were established which made low resistivity paths to reach the substrate. By the addition of CNTs into the silane matrix, not only compactness of the silane coatings but also the length of diffusion paths of the electrolyte through the coating to reach the metal increased therefore deterioration of the coating happened at a longer period.
Based on (C ¼ εε0A/d) when water defuses through the coating, permittivity of coating increases leading to a raise of coating capacitance. The elevation of the double layer capacitance depends on the amount of water absorbed on the coating/substrate interface and the adhesion of the coating to the substrate. By employing oxidized CNTs micro pores of the coating were filled resulted in lower double layer capacitance, and lower coating capacitance which followed the order Sil > SiC1>SiC2>SiC3 samples. This can be attributed to the functional groups of CNTs making bands with silane molecules forming a denser silane network with improved barrier protection.
Change in capacitance is due to the difference between water and coating permittivity. However, change in resistance originates from increase in concentration of ions in the water channels in the coatings. Water is the first step of a coating deterioration while the aggressive ions penetrate take place at a slower rate due to coating ionic resistance. This makes significant change in resistivity of the coating over immersion time. Considering the water uptake at the saturated level this change is

S. Akbarzadeh et al.
Composites Part B 175 (2019) 107109
not significant compared to the change in the resistivity of the conductive pathways by penetration of ions and enlargement of the pores [44,45].

sections.heading: 4.4. Water uptake results
sections.text:
In this work, the impedance of coating was equaled to theoretical coating impedance in the integral form through the MATLAB R2013a software and the absorbed water in the coating was estimated (Fig. 13). It is worth to note that for calculating the impedance of the coating from experimental data, the amount of the rest of the circuit elements should be known; therefore, we used the data obtained from Zview3.1c.
Dependence of φ(δ), γ, Rpore and Rct to the time of immersion are shown in Table 1. Each sample had ρc and εc of its own which was assumed as a fixed parameter during the dipping time. With increasing the immersion time, the mean water volume in the coating increased and the pore resistance and charge transfer resistance reduced. The pores were assumed as a cylindrical shape that made a low resistivity path to reach the substrate. This resistivity depended on both the nature of coating and electrolyte. According to the fact that the environment was the same for all samples, SiC3 showed the maximum pore resistance, minimum ξ and φ(δ) compared to the rest of the samples. Due to the power-law component, γ value, and its relation with α, it can be concluded that by an increase in the water volume in the coating, the coatings became rougher and/or electrochemically more heterogeneous. In other words, according to the γ values employing factionalized CNTs (C3, C2, and C1) improved the uniformity of the coatings [21].
The dependency of resistivity and permittivity profiles to ξ f of coated samples after 6 h immersion in 0.1 M NaCl solution is provided in Fig. 14. Dependence of ρ(ξ) – ξ illustrated in Fig. 14a showed a sensible improve in resistivity by the inclusion of oxidized CNTs. Application of the CNTs with higher oxidation degree in the silane coatings led to broadening of plateau region for ρ(ξ) which means the number of pores in the coating became less. Therefore, the pathways of water and aggressive ions to reach substrate were diminished upon inclusion of CNTs with a higher oxidation level. Looking at Fig. 14a, not only the plateau region was broadened, but also the resistivity of the coatings showed an increase by incorporation of higher oxidized CNTs. The extent of resistivity for these coatings followed the order: SiC3>SiC2>SiC1>Sil. The decrease in the numbers of pores and higher coating resistivity resulted in the enhancement of the coating protective performance. The dependency of ε(ξ) – ξ shown in Fig. 14b indicated that incorporation of the CNTs with a higher oxidation level in the coatings led to lower coating permittivity. The extent of permittivity for these coatings followed the order: Sil > SiC1>SiC2>SiC3. Similar to the resistivity profile, permittivity profile showed broadening by the inclusion of oxidized CNTs reflecting the restriction of pores in the silane coating.

sections.heading: 4.5. Polarization measurements
sections.text: Polarization curves of the coated sample after 6 h immersion in the 0.1 M NaCl are illustrated in Fig. 15. It was clear that for all kinds of incorporation of CNT in the silane coating, corrosion current reached to the lower values and the corrosion potential shifted to the more positive values. It means for SiC3, the corrosion current reached the lowest value which showed improvement of the coating performance and confirmed EIS results. The polarization curves showed that icorr from 3.98 μA/cm2 for Sil reached to 0.2 μA/cm2 for SiC3 indicating higher than 10 fold of decreasing in the corrosion current density.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusion
sections.text:
CNTs were functionalized by means of the mixture of H2SO4 and HNO3 at different times of oxidation (8, 12 and 24 h). FTIR spectra indicated the ability of the functionalized CNTs to make bands with
silane molecules to form a denser network. The water contact angle and SEM cross-sectional images confirmed the positive impact of the CNTs’ oxidation level on the silane films integrity. From EIS measurements, it was clear that by incorporation of functionalized CNTs in the silane solution, the anti-corrosion behavior was improved. During immersion time, the water diffused in the coating and the number of pores was increased which resulted in a decrease in pore resistance of the coatings. All the elements of the circuit (including electrolyte, charge transfer and pore resistance, CPE elements of the double layer and coating impedance) were considered for evaluation of coating impedance and water uptake assessment. It was shown that the higher extent of the oxidization of CNTs led to the less water uptake and permittivity, and higher coating resistivity. The approach reported in this work is a generalized form of the previous method and can be considered for estimation of water uptake in all coatings with two-constant impedance frequency response.

referenceMentions.context: Both resistance and capacitance of the coating change by water penetration [4].
Silane coatings have been attracted much attention according to the anti-corrosive and eco-friendly properties [6].

It was shown that due to the compatibility of functionalized GO nanofillers with silane matrix and blocking porosities in silane coatings through covalent bonding between silanol groups on the surface of functionalized nanofillers and silanol groups in the silane matrix the corrosion performance was enhanced [7].
Al-Saadi examined the corrosion performance of hexagonal boron nitride impregnated silane composite coating on the magnesium alloys substrate [8].

Due to the fact that even intact kinds of coatings have some pores or defects which causes water reaches the substrate [9], electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) providing the extent of coating capacitance is a popular technique to determine the absorbed water [10–12].

[15] applied Brasher and Kingsbury equation to show that the modified epoxy with γ-aminopropyltrimethoxy silane (γ-APS) absorbed less electrolyte than the neat one; therefore, had a better corrosion protective properties.
[16] made a comparison between impedance measurements and gravimetry to calculate water uptake in the water-based coatings containing SrCrO4 or a mixture of Cr (VI)-free pigments.
[17] employed Brasher and Kingsbury equation and two other models (the discrete (DM) and continuous (CM) models proposed by Bellucci and Nicodemo [18]) to evaluate the water absorption.
[17] employed Brasher and Kingsbury equation and two other models (the discrete (DM) and continuous (CM) models proposed by Bellucci and Nicodemo [18]) to evaluate the water absorption.

According to the fact that the surface roughness makes the coating a non-ideal capacitor and causes inhomogeneous water uptake in the film, employing capacitance instead of constant phase element (CPE) for evaluation of the water uptake may lead to incorrect results [19,20].

Achieving a denser silane film network by the inclusion of functionalized graphene oxide has been reported in the literature which is in good agreement with the results of this work [39].
Increase in compactness of silane network due to interaction with CNTs has been reported in the literature [41].

Also, phase angle diagrams clearly show that by embedding the oxidized CNTs into the silane matrix, the highfrequency phase angles shift to 90 reflecting improve in capacitive behavior and protective properties of the coatings [42].

metadata.abstractText: Water uptake is an influential parameter on the protective properties of coatings. Carbon nano-tubes (CNTs) with different oxidation levels were used in this work to decrease water uptake of silane composite coating. The water uptake of the single-layer coatings was monitored using electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS). In this assessment, power-law formula and effective medium theory (EMT) were exploited considering the parallel combination of the coating and electrolyte. EIS results showed that an increase in oxidation level of CNTs improved the protective functioning of the silane sol-gel coatings due to decrease in water uptake of the coatings.
metadata.creator: Elsevier
